title: Blind XSS in the rocket.chat registration email

profile.name: Rocket.Chat
profile.about: Rocket.Chat is a company built on open source values and a love for efficiency. The company is driven by our amazing community of contributors.

activities.message:
Hi Ed,

thanks for reaching out and reporting this to us in such a detailed manner.

I'm going to contact our developers to see who can take a look at this.

Best regards.
Jonas
@edoverflow can you explain me how this could be exploited since it's an email and would be rendered by the email client?

Hi @rodrigok,

I totally see what you mean, it is definitely confusing referring to this as "XSS" in the context of an email client. That being said, as an adversary, being able to control the contents of an email's HTML body coming from a trusted source ‚Äî particularly important since that will evade any spam filters ‚Äî means that I can easily trick a Rocket.chat administrator. One could inject tracking code ‚Äî as demonstrated with the HTML5 canvas screenshot of the email ‚Äî and malicious links inside of the email body.

Personally, if I were in the position of an administrator, I would not want my users to be able to control the HTML contents of an email body being sent to my inbox from what appears to be Rocket.chat. Especially when the email's purpose it to be reviewed by the administrator.

To summarise, I would probably classify this as a viable means of phishing that is probably far more convincing than your bog-standard phishing email.

I hope that clears things up. Please let me know if you need any further information.

\- Ed

@edoverflow thanks, that clarify the issue, we will add this to our development board and will update the status soon.

Thanks

additional_data.old_title: Blind XSS in the rocket.chat Android client.
additional_data.new_title: Blind XSS in the rocket.chat registration email

activities.message: @edoverflow here is the Pull Request fixing the issue https://github.com/RocketChat/Rocket.Chat/pull/11644

Hi @rodrigok,

Nice work! It looks like you have covered all the cases where user input is sent via email in that pull request.

\- Ed
@edoverflow can you test using our release candidate version? https://www.npmjs.com/package/dompurifyhttps://github.com/RocketChat/Rocket.Chat/releases/tag/0.69.0-rc.0

Hi @rodrigok, I will get to work on testing the new release. I would just like to point out something, it appears that one of your developers tested the vulnerability using my payload from this report. I beleive the developer is Tasso Evangelista and they might have leaked important information to me. {F337531} The payload fired in the context of `http://0.0.0.0:1080/email/wWKkV3yh/html`, leaking the developer's IP address (`189.6.XXX.XXX`) and cookies (`rc_uid=Tdjm7ck8PvufbQEt7; rc_token=JjkVGMkpPhW91xe5bFjTpX84Fin3pq9DengXKwuBW9Z`). Here is the full DOM output: ```html

Rocket.Chat

The user Tasso (tasso.evangelista.3@rocket.cat) has been registered.

Reason: ">

Please check "Administration -> Users" to activate or delete it.
Powered by Rocket.Chat
``` When testing these types of issues in future, I highly recommend *not* using my personal payload. You can create an account on https://xsshunter.com/ and use your own payload. This is just to make sure you do not accidentally leak sensitive information to the reporter in future.

@edoverflow To be honest, I knew that I did something terribly wrong (imagining that the client of development SMTP server wouldn't render the email) but I was expecting to go unnoticed :) Thank you for warn us.

No worries, @tassoevan, just thought I would bring this to your attention in case there was anything sensitive in the output and I also wanted to let you know about https://xsshunter.com/. I have deleted all the data I retrieved from my XSSHunter dashboard.
Thank you, @tassoevan. It is an absolute pleasure to work with you. I would, hereby, kindly request we publicly disclose this report in order to inform fellow researchers on HackerOne.
@edoverflow we will discloser this in 30 days to give time for the current users to update their installations.
@edoverflow We're keeping a policy of waiting for 30 days before fully disclose it, since this issue is related to our code base and can affect many users.
